author: Meteorologist Violet Scibior
title: chevron-right
text: Cortland Police Chief Paul Sandy is retiring from the police force after more than 38 years of service, according to a statement from the Cortland Police Department. In November 1985, Sandy began his career with Cortland police. He was promoted to sergeant in July 1993 and was assigned to the detective bureau in October 1995. In 2009, Sandy was promoted to Deputy Chief of Police and remained in that role until 2021, when he was promoted to chief. Sandy is a graduate of the FBI national academy and is also a member of the New York State Chiefs of Police Association and the International Association of Chiefs of Police. He was involved in implementing the Cortland Police Department's tactical and bicycle patrol units, which are still active today, according to the department. During his career, Sandy was also an active member of the Cortland County Drug Task Force and he oversaw hundreds of investigations and successful prosecutions, according to the department. In a statement, the Cortland Police Department praised Sandy for his service. "Your dedication will leave a lasting impression for years to come," the statement said.
